orientation.title: What Is Photography?
orientation.statement:
Photography, at its most basic level, is the capture of light within a space.

Yet contemporary image-making complicates this seemingly simple definition. Processes now exist that simulate, reconstruct, or generate images without traditional photographic methods.

In this installation, you are the curator.

You will be shown a series of works. Each is preceded by text — sometimes a question, sometimes a statement — that frames the work in a particular way.

Your task is to decide whether each work belongs in your exhibition.

Your decisions will determine the shape of the installation you create.

works.framing_text: If photography is an index of light, must light be present for something to be considered a photograph?
works.context_text: Black image produced by exposing photographic film with the lens cap in place. No external light reached the photosensitive surface during exposure.

works.framing_text: Must a photograph reflect human perception to be considered photography?
works.context_text: Camera-less image created by exposing photographic film directly to light. No lens or representational subject was used in the process.
